instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
No liquid spill. Tested with KG screen.
pin 1 on LVDS / 0v pin 28-9-30 5v
F7700 /12.57V
<RESISTOR>R7700</RESISTOR>/12.57
<CAPACITOR>C7700</CAPACITOR>/12.57V
<RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>- PIN1 -12.57 PIN2 12.47 80k
<RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR> - PIN 1 12.46V - PIN 2 12.37V 63.3K
<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> - Enable PIN 2 3.332V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Makes no sense. Pin 2 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> is an output pin no ENABLE. But looking at <RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>/02 then <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> is not turned on
Did you test with a good screen from 2015/16 nothing else works. If yes then first check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> then replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> and check if fuse is good of course.

Damn it! off course its not pin 2 it is pin 17 (the secound in that row :rolleyes:)  yes i tested with 2 different screens for the same model/year.

threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>?? Are you 100% sure you check with a known good 2015 LCD? inspect LCD connector for damage to. Only then you touch <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Because 1.99V is not right! Should be at least 3.2V. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is the issue here.
So corrosion on HAL sensor or trackpad/connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Davis, post: 14566"]

duke you seems like a quick guy but If you didn't noticed it yet I am a newbie to the board repair and that is the reason I pay a subscription on this site actually to get better, but if you can't handle this il pay another one to help me with my oops..remember your oops as a newbie or close this forum.[/QUOTE]

[URL="https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/5371-forum-rules"]Rule #3[/URL] is proficiency with a multimeter.

This is a serious, and probably the most important rule. We are trying to help you without being in front of the board you are working on. The only way this is possible is if we receive accurate measurements from you. The advice we give you on what to replace, or what to do, directly correlates to whether you tell us 3.42v or 1.5v on a given line. There is no compromise here: newbie or not, basic multimeter proficiency is an absolute requirement before someone can do any type of component level board diagjosis or repair.

For example: a medical student may be a newbie to brain surgery, but it wouldn't be unreasonable to expect that they understand how to use a scalpel or administer general anesthetic. These two basic skillsets must be mastered before one can commence learning or taking part in brain surgery. The same way that, while you may be a newbie to component level board repair, we don't find it unreasonable that you be able to interpret & provide accurate multimeter measurements.

If any of these rules are a dealkiller, we will not close the forum, but highly suggest you unsubscribe. I don't mean this to be mean - but there's no one out there who is going to provide proper help if they can't make the reasonable demand of you that you provide accurate measurements for them to work with. We are upfront with the rules of this forum that while we are happy to provide you with a wealth of diagnostic troubleshooting advice, it [I]must [/I]be based on solid measurements.

When <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.42v, it thinks the screen is open. When <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is below 3v, it thinks the screen is closed, which points to a bad sleep sensor, or corrosion under the SMC. When <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.42v, it points to a problem with the backlight circuit. We're going to tell you to do very different things based on the voltage you read on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>, so it is imperative that this be correct!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: I cannot give any advise when you give bad information. The quality of my advice is as good as the information you provide me. I need to at least know that you are able to use a multimeter and probe the correct part as I cannot see what you are actually doing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
It was all about the attitude if the measurements was wrong one could think it is because the lid was close which it probably was so just ask the right questions instead of rolling eyes on those newbies, I know where it comes from since I advice newbies in other levels, find the patience and ask the right questions thats all Im asking for.

Ok please lets proceed to the case.
I now replaced <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7700</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>, F7700, <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>, <RESISTOR>R7733</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7740</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7744</RESISTOR> AND LVDS connector and yes tested with other displays but still no backlight!
try to guide me out Im probably missing something basic..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: Check pins 15 and 16 for continuity to LCD connector. Also check the pull up resistors on those lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 14802"]Check pins 15 and 16 for continuity to LCD connector. Also check the pull up resistors on those lines.[/QUOTE]

15+16 continuity is good though I'm not sure about the pull up resistors, can you send me the part number on the .brd?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR>/53. Also check diode mode on these lines. There is not much else to this anymore. You did try a known good LCD from the correct model year??
